repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Education Modernization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Modernization
            Project for Former Yugoslav Republic (FYR) of Macedonia were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk
            to development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: successful
            management of modern educational systems and related
            effective policies are strongly related to a culture of
            monitoring routines at all levels. A participatory approach
            is a key element to the successful implementation of an
            education project which has at its core decentralization,
            and community participation. After establishing an effective
            in-service teacher training in FYR Macedonia, including
            training providers and designing procedures, the challenge
            to its continuation remains its financing. The analysis on
            the required resources to maintain this system should have
            been completed before project closure, in order to help
            Ministry of Education and Science (MoES) to plan resources,
            and guide the policy dialogue with MoES.

Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Education Modernization Project

repnme.cdata!:
Modernizing schools in FYR Macedonia for
            better learning outcomes

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            modernizing schools in FYR Macedonia for better learning
            outcomes. The World Bank joined FYR Macedonia's efforts
            to bolster the quality of education through an Education
            Modernization Project. It improved the school
            infrastructure, strengthened student safety and hygiene, and
            provided teacher training and teaching aids. As part of
            modernizing the country's education, the Ministry of
            Education was connected to all of the primary and secondary
            schools and to municipalities and provided access to
            reliable and up-to-date information on the teaching process,
            students, and human resources

docna.cdata!:
Modernizing schools in FYR Macedonia for
            better learning outcomes

repnme.cdata!:
Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia -
            Reforming education system for improved learning outcomes

abstracts.cdata!:
This result profile talks about the
            Education Modernization Project in the  Formerthe Former
            Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.The aim of the project was to
            decentralize education administration to municipalities,
            improve teachers’ professional development, expand access to
            education, and improve the assessment and evaluation of the
            system. The government enlisted the World Bank’s aid to help
            with this reform initiative, which has helped boost
            secondary school enrollments, establish training options for
            teachers, and create a better learning environment in schools.

repnme.cdata!:
Macedonia, former Yugoslav Republic of -
            Education Modernization Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Education
            Modernization Project for Macedonia is to improve the
            quality of learning and participation at the targeted
            schools by strengthening school level planning and
            management; and improved equity and efficiency for a
            decentralized education system. It is the Bank'
            assessment that a four month extension would be prudent to
            ensure the completion of all activities undertaken in the
            second round of the school improvement grants program and to
            allow loan proceeds to be fully disbursed. The Ministry of
            education and science has prepared an action plan for
            completion of the remaining activities reflecting the
            extension of four months. The plan has been closely reviewed
            by the Bank team during the supervision visit in the week of
            September 11, 2010 and has been found acceptable. There are
            no outstanding audits for this project. The World Bank
            concurred with borrower's request for one year
            extension dated March 31, 2009.

repnme.cdata!:
Partners in learning : improving the
            education system in Macedonia

abstracts.cdata!:
Macedonia recognized the need to reform
            its education system after emerging from civil conflict in
            2001. The government enlisted the International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development’s (IBRD) aid to help schools
            better cope with a range of challenges, from poor teacher
            development to weak enrollment policies. As a result,
            Macedonia has boosted secondary school enrollment,
            established training options for teachers, and now reports
            higher student achievement.

            sistema educativo en Macedonia
